GRETCHEN WHITMER DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ELIZABETH HERTEL

Jennifer Vasilovski
Family and Community Services-Livingston
Suite 116
3075 E. Grand River Ave.
Howell, MI 48843
RE: License #: CB470382419
Investigation #: 2021C0212027
Family and Community Services-Livingston
Dear Ms. Vasilovski:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure
611 W. OTTAWA  P.O. BOX 30664  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/lara  517-335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB470382419
Investigation #: 2021C0212027
Complaint Receipt Date: 07/21/2021
Investigation Initiation Date: 07/22/2021
Report Due Date: 09/19/2021
Licensee Name: Family & Community Services Inc
Licensee Address: Suite 110
42140 Van Dyke Ave
Sterling Heights, MI 48317
Licensee Telephone #: (330) 297-7027
Administrator: Jennifer Vasilovski, Designee
Licensee Designee: Jennifer Vasilovski, Designee
Name of Facility: Family and Community Services-Livingston
Facility Address: Suite 116
3075 E. Grand River Ave.
Howell, MI 48843
Facility Telephone #: (586) 726-2988
Original Issuance Date: 11/16/2016
License Status: REGULAR
Effective Date: 05/16/2021
Expiration Date: 05/15/2023
Capacity: Unknown
Program Type: CHILD PLACING AGENCY, PRIVATE
1

II. ALLEGATIONS
Violation
Established?
Agency has not followed through with dental and vision care as No
required.
Staff are not meeting with youth monthly. No
Staff allowed children to stay in an unsafe foster home. No
Staff are falsely reporting information. No
Children are not receiving therapy as required. No
III. METHODOLOGY
07/21/2021 Special Investigation Intake
2021C0212027
07/22/2021 Special Investigation Initiated - Telephone
07/26/2021 Contact - Face to Face
Staff interviews completed on-site.
07/27/2021 Contact - Document Received
Email from Complainant
07/27/2021 Contact - Document Received
Email from Parent 1. Six emails on 7/27/21. Follow-up on 7/28,
7/30, 8/2, 8/27, 8/29 and 8/31/21.
07/28/2021 Contact - Document Received
Received additional information from Complainant
07/29/2021 Contact - Telephone call made
phone interview with staff
07/30/2021 Contact - Document Received
Received additional information from Complainant.
08/02/2021 Contact - Document Received
Reviewed MISACWIS
08/22/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Follow-up email with Administrator- 8/24/21, 8/29/21, 8/30/21
08/26/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Email follow-up with FC Supervisor 8/27/21, 8/30/21
08/30/2021 Contact - Document Received
Received additional information from Complainant
2

08/31/2021 Contact - Telephone call made
Phone interview with former foster parent
08/31/2021 Contact - Telephone call made
Phone interview with foster parent
08/31/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Email with DHHS Program Manager
08/31/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Email with Parent Education worker
08/31/2021 Contact - Document Received
Additional document review
08/31/2021 Contact - Telephone call made
Phone call with Chief Administrator Pre-exit
09/01/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Follow-up with Complainant
09/01/2021 Pre-exit with DCWL Manager
On 7/21/21 it was reported to DCWL that the foster care agency was not providing required
services. The following examples were provided:
 Youth A has had 15-30 cavities since coming into care and has not had them treated
timely.
 Youth A and Youth B are overdue for eye exams.
 Staff have perjured themselves in court and fabricated incidents in order to keep the
case open.
 The children were in extremely dangerous situations where they were starved and
abused mentally and physically by a foster parent and dangerous child in the home.
 The children’s former foster parent was an alcoholic.
 The agency did not allow the children to attend their sister’s high school graduation.
 Children’s Protective Services was not truthful from the beginning of the case.
 The agency has not provided therapy as court ordered.
 The agency has not completed monthly visits with the children.
 The agency lied in court about completing Family Team Meetings.
 The judge does not allow the children or their mother to talk in court
 The children’s Guardian Ad-Litem has never met the children or their mother.
 The agency intentionally causes emotional distress.
3

The complainant was informed that DCWL can only investigate matters that fall under
DCWL licensing rules and a DHHS contract with the private agency. Matters involving the
court, LGAL, and CPS are outside of the scope of DCWL. It was clarified for the
complainant that this investigation would focus on the agency’s compliance with health care
(including vision, dental and eye exams), therapy services, safety in the previous
placement, family team meetings, and foster home visits.
ALLEGATION:
Agency has not followed through with dental and vision care as required.
INVESTIGATION:
On 7/21/21 Parent 1 was contacted about the allegations and reported Youth A had 15-30
cavities since coming into care (December 2019), after having no cavities prior to foster
care. Youth A saw a dentist in July 2021 to have some fillings done, after months of
waiting. Parent 1 reported that this matter has been resolved at this time.
Chief Administrator
On 7/22/21 the agency’s Chief Administrator (CA) was informed of the allegations and
reported anticipating the investigation as the children’s mother (Parent 1) has been very
vocal about her dissatisfaction with the case direction.
Supervisor
On 7/26/21 the Supervisor was interviewed at the agency. The Supervisor reported the
case has been open since late 2019, although not adjudicated yet due to delays from
COVID-19 and Parent 1’s desire to have a jury trial. The trial was scheduled for August
2021. A follow-up call occurred with the CA on 8/31/21. The CA reported that court found
Parent 1 to be guilty and adjudicated the case on 8/26/21.
The Supervisor reported Youth A and Youth B have had several dental exams since
coming into care. Youth A did not have 15-30 cavities, although he did have several. Many
of the cavities occurred while Youth A was living with Parent 1 or the relative caregiver. An
initial dental exam was completed on 2/1/20. Follow up exams were slightly delayed due to
the global pandemic (COVID-19) that began in March 2020 and caused businesses to
close and the state to be in lockdown. Follow-up dental exams were completed in
September, and November 2020, March, June, and July 2021. The supervisor noted that
during the July dental visit, Youth A threw a needle at the dentist. Youth A was then
referred to a pediatric dentist on 8/10/21.
Regarding eye exams, Parent 1 did not initially tell the agency the children may need
glasses. The children did not come in to care with glasses and did not inform the worker of
any vision problems. Parent 1 did not mention the vision needs until the children moved
from the relative caregiver’s home and into a foster home that Parent 1 did not like.
Parent 1
On 7/27/21 Parent 1 provided additional information regarding the allegation. Parent 1
stated that Youth A and Youth B were over six months late for eye exams. Parent 1
4

reported that Youth A is farsighted and needs glasses; Youth B has a cataract that needs
attention. Parent 1 provided two text message screen shots of a conversation with the
worker, which Parent 1 felt was evidence of the agency refusing to provide these services.
Additionally, Parent 1 reported that staff do not notify her of medical appointments, despite
stating she could attend them.
The text screen shots from Parent 1 were reviewed. The first message was from April 19
(year unspecified), from Parent 1 to the Foster Care Worker (FCW). The message was
Parent 1 telling the FCW that Youth A’s eye exam was months overdue and accusing the
FCW of refusing to discuss it. The second message was a response from the FCW on July
12 (year unspecified) stating that Youth A and Youth B had eye appointments scheduled
for July 15.
Parent 1 also provided a text message conversation between the FCW and herself, which
she believed was evidence of the FCW not allowing her to attend medical appointments.
The text was reviewed and found the FCW provided Parent 1 with the date/time of a dental
appointment, while trying to schedule a video conference. Parent 1 then asked if she could
attend the dental appointment. The FCW did not respond.
Foster Care Worker
On 7/29/21 an interview was completed with the assigned Foster Care Worker (FCW). The
FCW reported the children have attended their well-child exams and dental exams as
required by policy. None of their medical care is overdue. When the FCW was assigned to
the case she completed a case review and found that, as noted on the initial dental exam,
Youth A entered foster care with cavities. Therefore, the worker believes any concerns
about the children being neglected in care, resulting in cavities, are unfounded. Any
cavities that have been found, have been addressed, or are in the process of treatment.
The FCW noted some delay in 2020, due to dental offices closing during the COVID-19
pandemic.
The FCW reported that neither the children nor their mother identified any concerns about
their vision until April 2021. Once the FCW was informed of Parent 1’s concern about their
vision, the Foster Parent (FP) was contacted and instructed to schedule eye exams. The
FP had some difficulty finding a provider that would accept the children’s insurance. An
eye exam was completed in July 2021. The FCW noted the case file indicated that neither
youth wore glasses when they entered care in 2019. Nor did they express they were
missing glasses or had any difficulty with their vision.
Foster Parent 1
Foster Parent 1 (FP1) stated that he had placement of the children for approximately six
months. At the time he accepted placement, a dental exam was already scheduled.
Although the dental office was approximately an hour away, he kept the appointment.
When he and the kids arrived at the appointment with Parent 1, they learned it had been
cancelled. FP1 rescheduled the appointment for 11/5/20 to have four cavities filled for
Youth A. However, on the day of that appointment Youth A and Parent 1 asked that only
two cavities be filled, as they wanted to go out to dinner for the anniversary of the children’s
5

father passing. The dentist filled two cavities on 11/5/20 and planned to do the other two at
a later appointment in December. However, due to Youth B complaining about her mouth
hurting, Parent 1 canceled the December appointment and scheduled an earlier
appointment at another dental office. When they arrived at the appointment, FP1 learned it
was an emergency dental office, and they would not do any of the work for 6-8 weeks.
Before the next appointment took place, FP1 requested removal of both children. FP1
reported no difficulties with the children or the agency. The reason for replacement was due
to disruptive and harassing behavior by Parent 1.
FP1 reported that neither child wore glasses while placed in the home. Neither child ever
mentioned previously having or needing glasses, or any difficulty with vision or headaches
that might indicate a problem.
Documents reviewed
 A review of MiSACWIS confirmed an eye exam occurred for Youth A and Youth B
on 7/15/21. Youth A and Youth B were prescribed glasses. A cataract was not
documented for Youth B.
 Initial intake paperwork was reviewed and found no indication by Parent 1 or DHHS
that either child needed an eye exam, wore glasses, or had vision trouble.
 A review of all Family Team Meetings found no mention of either child needing eye
exams.
 The children’s case file documented several dental exams in 2020 and 2021 for
Youth A. Youth A was treated for six cavities from February 2020 to November
2020. The file documented that Youth B also had multiple dental exams in 2020 and
one in April 2021. Two cavities were found and treated, with some delay due to
COVID-19 and offices being closed. It was further noted that medical exams were
completed timely for Youth A and Youth B in 2020 and 2021.
 Contacts in MiSACWIS and texts provided by Parent 1, showed communications
from the FCW notifying Parent 1 of upcoming medical and dental appointments.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any
treatment required for each child who is 4 years of age and
older, including both of the following:
(ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least
every 18 months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
ANALYSIS: There was no information found to support the allegation.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
6

ALLEGATION:
Staff are not meeting with youth monthly.
INVESTIGATION:
Parent 1 reported the agency lies in court, claiming to have completed foster home visits
which have not occurred. Parent 1 also reported that staff do not return her calls or respond
to emails and often shorten her parenting time, in order to discuss the case.
Supervisor and FCW
During interviews with the FCW and Supervisor, both staff reported that all home visits
were completed as reported. The FCW noted that during recent foster home visits, the
children have not been receptive to speaking with her and have made threats about hurting
her. The FCW indicated this is related to how their mother has discussed people involved in
the case. The FCW further reported that she will continue to visit the children monthly and
attempt to engage with them, even if they are not responsive.
Both staff reported that Parent 1 will call, text, and email several times a day and become
hostile when she feels they are not responding to her. Staff have been trying to engage
with her as necessary, but not feed into unrealistic expectations of communication. Parent
1 has been rude, harassing, and threatening toward staff. If staff do not respond to her
immediately, she will keep calling until they do. Parent 1 also records all interactions and
posts many of them online.
The FCW noted that she has asked Parent 1 to come to parenting time early on occasions
to review the treatment plan, discuss referrals, or other case matters. The intent is to
handle these issues prior to the visit time. However, Parent 1 has not arrived on time for
these discussions, which then spills into scheduled parenting time. The FCW stated that
parenting time has never been cut short and that extra time has been allowed when
needed.
Foster Parents
On 8/31/21 interviews were conducted with the children’s current; Foster Parent 2 (FP2)
and former foster parent; Foster Parent 1 (FP1). The foster parents reported that a foster
care worker had visited the home each month and observed and/or spoke with the children,
for the duration of their placement in the foster homes.
Documents reviewed
 A review of the children’s case record found monthly foster home visits completed
for the duration of the case. It was noted that some visits were completed virtually,
via video call, due to COVID-19 restrictions in early 2020 and a time in 2021 when
the foster family had to quarantine due to a COVID-19 exposure.
 Parenting time notes were reviewed and found to be consistent with the information
reported by the foster care worker.
7

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the
following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child and the foster parent in the foster parent's home at
least once every month.
(c) Provisions for visits between parents and children
except where parental rights have been terminated or when
there is a court determination that visits are detrimental to
the child.
ANALYSIS: There was no information found to support the allegation.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
Staff allowed children to stay in an unsafe foster home.
INVESTIGATION:
Parent 1 reported the agency allowed her children to reside in a foster home which “starved
and abused (them) mentally and physically”. Parent 1 did not provide further details.
Supervisor
During an interview with the Supervisor, she reported that while the children were placed
with Foster Parent 1, Parent 1 made several allegations. Initially, Parent 1 and Foster
Parent 1 got along well. But then Parent 1 began making claims the foster parent was
speeding, using alcohol, and not protecting the children from another child in the home.
Foster Parent 1 eventually put in a request to have the children removed, due to threats
and harassment by Parent 1. The Supervisor did not have any concerns about the safety of
the foster home.
Foster Care Worker
FCW indicated that Parent 1 and Foster Parent 1 initially got along. Parenting time was
occurring at the foster home and they were going on outings together with the children. But
then Parent 1 began making allegations, which were dismissed by DHHS (Children’s
Services). The allegations include reports that Youth A was not being treated fairly and was
being mistreated by another child in the home. Parent 1 also reported the kids did not eat
enough at the foster home. The FCW reported having several conversations with both
children, in which they reported having enough food and being able to get snacks
whenever they want. The FCW had also observed, and took pictures of the food in the
8

home, and determined there was sufficient food in the home for all residents. The FCW did
not have any concerns about Foster Parent 1 or the children’s safety in the home.
Foster Parent 1
FP1 reported that while things started out well with Youth A and Youth B in the home, they
quickly changed. FP1 stated that Parent 1 inserted herself in every situation, often creating
problems with the children and the agency. The kids were well behaved while in his home
and got along well with another child in the home that was in the process of being adopted.
The other child in the home was cognitively impaired, autistic, and diagnosed with
Oppositional Defiance Disorder. FP1 stated that the kids would have disagreements at
times, but nothing violent. Youth B enjoyed spending time with the other child. While Youth
A would aggravate the other child at times and then tell on her, or tell his mother about it,
which would result in an allegation.
FP1 gave the example of one incident where the adoptive child became upset, FP1 told
Youth A and Youth B to go into the bathroom, so they would be safe if the other child
became physically aggressive. Youth A later told Parent 1 that they were locked in the
bathroom. Which was untrue. Parent 1 filed a report with DHHS. This was one of many
allegations Parent 1 made. FP1 denied all of the allegations, indicating the agency
previously investigated them and found the allegations to be false. Specifically FP1 stated
that the children always had meals and snacks to eat. No one was ever hungry in the
home. FP1 also stated the children were always safe in the home.
Documents reviewed
A review of the foster home file found that three special evaluations were completed while
Youth A and Youth B were placed there. The investigations did not determine any
violations regarding Parent 1’s concerns nor were there any finding of the children being
abused or neglected.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in
the agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule: (a) Submit a
special investigation record to the department’s licensing
authority within 5 working days in the manner prescribed
by the department. (b) Initiate a special evaluation of the
foster home as soon as is indicated, based on the
information received, but not later tan 7 calendar days after
receipt of the information.
ANALYSIS: There was no information found to support the allegation.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
9

ALLEGATION:
Staff are falsely reporting information.
INVESTIGATION:
Parent 1 reported the agency perjured themselves in court by reporting dates of Family
Team Meetings and home visits that did not happen. Parent 1 did not indicate any specific
dates of FTMs or home visits that were falsely reported. Parent 1 further indicated the
agency has lied and stated she was a drug user. Parent 1 also reported the agency was
lying in their most recent report to the court and intentionally left out a “very positive” report
from the parenting coach she is working with. Parent 1 indicated the agency left positive
information out because it did not support “the narrative presented” by the FCW and
Supervisor. Indicating the agency lies in order to keep her children in foster care.
Parent 1 provided several documents to DCWL, which she believed would confirm her
allegations:
 Parent 1 provided a link to a ‘Youtube’ video she uploaded, which was an audio
recording of a court hearing from 3/1/21. The video was very difficult to understand.
Accompanying the video was copies of correspondence she had with law
enforcement, when she attempted to press charges of perjury against the former
foster care worker. Ultimately, the law enforcement officer informed Parent 1 there
was no violation of criminal law to pursue charges.
 Parent 1 provided a video, which she indicated would prove the “gratuitous
mishandling” of the family’s case and “misconduct” that occurred. The video was a
recorded phone conversation between Parent 1 and her mother, in which Parent 1 is
stating she was late for a meeting, but it did not matter. There was no information to
support misconduct by anyone at the agency.
 Parent 1 provided a letter written by the parenting coach. The letter indicated that
Parent 1 demonstrates love and affection with her children. However, she would
benefit from Parenting Education services (beginning on 8/26/21). These services
are intended to allow the parent to work on power struggles, nurturing discipline, and
positive communication. It further stated that weekly family counseling was
recommended to work on negative relational habits that are part of the family
dynamic.
 Parent 1 provided a copy of a drug test dated 8/16/21, indicating that it would prove
the agency is lying about her using drugs. The drug screen was reviewed and found
that Parent 1 was positive for marijuana.
Supervisor
Supervisor reported that all home visits and FTMs occurred as documented. The
caseworkers have not lied in court. Although there was one situation where a worker sent a
court report to Parent 1’s attorney and did not send a copy to Parent 1. This was discussed
and resolved in court. However, Parent 1 believed it was perjury when the worker said she
sent the report, only to later realize she forgot to copy Parent 1 on the email. The court did
not view this as perjury, as the worker was not under oath, and the report was provided to
the parent’s legal representative.
10

Supervisor reported Parent 1 is prescribed Suboxone and admitted to using Fentanyl until
2019, and smoking marijuana currently. This information was provided in court accurately.
However, drug screens had not yet been court ordered.
Foster Care Worker
The FCW reported that Parent 1 previously claimed she was not being invited to FTMs.
She later said that she “found” the invitations in her email. The agency is now emailing and
texting all FTM invites.
The FCW reported all FTMs and home visits have occurred as documented while she has
been assigned to the case. The FCW was not aware of any fraudulent reporting by the
agency and denied withholding information that would benefit Parent 1’s case.
Foster Parent 1
FP1 reported that all monthly home visits had been completed by case workers. In addition,
FP1 stated that Parent 1 participated in all FTMs that he was involved in. FP1 did not
believe the agency falsified any records.
Foster Parent 2
FP2 reported that all monthly home visits had been completed by case workers. FP2 also
reported that, to her knowledge, Parent 1 was involved in every FTM since the children
were placed in her home. FP2 was not aware of the agency falsifying any records.
DHHS Program Manager
On 8/31/21 the DHHS Program Manager (PM) was contacted and asked if there were any
concerns about how the agency is handling the case or concerns about the agency
fabricating any information. The PM responded there have been no concerns with the
agency. DHHS has been supportive of the agency as the case has been challenging. The
PM reported that Parent 1 has been making allegations and accusations toward everyone
involved in the case, since the beginning. Initially Parent 1 claimed the Children’s Services
worker lied about her in order to remove the children. Parent 1 records every conversation,
with the intent of using it as “evidence” against the agency.
Parenting Coach
On 9/1/21 the Parenting Coach confirmed writing the letter that was provided to DCWL by
Parent 1. Parenting Coach clarified that Parent 1 initially started with Parenting Time
Support, which occurs during parenting time and provides feedback and intervention when
needed. After receiving this service for some time, Parent 1 was then recommended for
Parenting Education, which is a one to one, intensive in-home program that provides
parents with tools.
Documents reviewed
 A review of Youth A and Youth B’s case records was completed. The review found
several FTMs that had occurred from December 2019 to July 2021. Each FTM
11

indicated that Parent 1 attended the meeting either in person, or via phone/video
due to COVID-19.
 As noted under rule R400.12421 (b), this investigation determined there was no
indication of staff falsifying home visits.
 Service plans from January 2020 to May 2021 were reviewed. All information
reviewed is consistent with information provided by agency staff, DHHS staff, and
service providers in this investigation. In addition, there were several documented
instances of Parent 1 being verbally abusive and threatening toward agency staff,
DHHS staff, and other service providers. Parent 1 was also documented to make
false allegations and encourage Youth A and B to act inappropriately toward agency
staff. This behavior could impact her credibility as a witness to potential wrongdoing
by the agency.
APPLICABLE RULE
PA 116 Investigation, inspection, and examination…
722.120
Sec. 10. (1) The department may investigate, inspect, and
examine conditions of a child-care organization and may
investigate and examine the books and records of the
licensee. The licensee shall cooperate with the
department's investigation, inspection, and examination by
doing all of the following: (c) Providing accurate and
truthful information to the department, and encouraging
witnesses, such as staff and household members, to
provide accurate and truthful information to the
department.
ANALYSIS: There was no information found to support the allegation.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
Children are not receiving therapy as required.
INVESTIGATION:
Parent 1 reported that Youth A and Youth B were court ordered into therapy at court on
February 1, 2021 but have not attended a one-on-one session yet.
Supervisor
Supervisor reported Youth A and Youth B were court ordered into therapy in March 2021.
The children were previously on a waiting list for a provider in February 2021. However,
their placement changed in March 2021 and they were placed on another waiting list with
Community Mental Health (CMH). Therapy services then began in June 2021.
12

Foster Care Worker
The FCW reported initially Parent 1 refused to sign a release for Youth B to receive therapy
services at CMH. Eventually Parent 1 signed the release and Youth B was placed on a
waiting list in the county of her placement. Youth A was also placed on the waiting list.
Youth B then moved and was placed on another waiting list. Services were further delayed
when Parent 1 decided not to sign some of the intake paperwork for Youth A and Youth B.
Parent 1 eventually returned the paperwork, although it was incomplete. Regardless,
therapy services began and Youth A and Youth B were seen every other week, while the
therapist determined a clear picture of goals. The therapists plan was to develop a
treatment plan and begin seeing both youths weekly. It is anticipated that weekly therapy
will begin in September 2021.
Foster Parent 2
FP2 reported both Youth A and Youth B are in bi-weekly therapy. The therapist expressed
wanting to do some sessions of ‘discovery’ before developing a treatment plan and moving
into individual sessions. FP2 reported that both children have been attending their therapy
sessions. FP2 reported there was initially some delay in starting therapy due to a wait list
with CMH and Parent 1 refusing to complete necessary paperwork.
Documents reviewed
 A court hearing summary from 2/1/21 was reviewed and found no services ordered,
as the review was adjourned to 3/1/21. Court hearing summaries from 3/1/21 and
3/23/21 were reviewed and found no therapy services ordered.
 A review of the children’s case records found that Youth A and Youth B were
referred to therapy services on 5/4/21, after concerns were reported by Parent 1 and
Foster Parent 2.
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 802 Mental health, behavioral and developmental needs of
Pages 1-2 children under the supervision of MDHHS
The caseworker’s role in the mental health screening
process includes the following:
 Completes the appropriate referrals for services if the
primary care provider indicates a need for further
evaluation or services.
 Contacts the child’s mental health provider,
Community Mental Health or the behavioral health
division of the child’s MHP to schedule an
appointment for an assessment if a significant
concern about a child’s mental health or behavior
arises between well child exams.
13

ANALYSIS: There was no information found to support the allegation.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend no change to the current status license.
September 9, 2021
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 10, 2021
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
14
